EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 11.3.1, Disclosure of Official Information, Introduction to Disclosure, dated 12, 2021.
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards
Table of Contents

) The Disclosure program provides oversight of Servicewide Disclosure policy, including guidance in administering the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), and Privacy Act (PA), and Internal Revenue Code (IRC) section

) Purpose: This IRM provides an introduction to the Disclosure program and provides a general overview of every IRS employee’s responsibility to conﬁdentiality of records and information entrusted to the IRS. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Director of Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safe- guards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (

) Program Owner: The Disclosure office, under GLDS, is responsible for the closure program and guidance. Each IRS organization is responsible for ensuring its employees are aware of and follow Servicewide Disclosure (

) Primary Stakeholders: All IRS business units and functions, state tax and federal agencies that receive tax returns and return information, individuals and organizations that request IRS records, the Treasury General for Tax Administration (TIGTA), contractors and Congress. (

) Every IRS employee, contractor and stakeholder who has access to Federal Tax Information (FTI) , Privacy Act information or Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) formation is responsible to protect it from unauthorized access, use or disclosure. Likewise, every person has a responsibility to know when a sure is authorized. This is a basic tenant of tax administration. This IRM section provides an overview and basic introduction to disclosure with a on FTI. (
) For additional guidance on disclosures involving other sensitive information refer to the following resources: • Privacy Act - IRM
, Privacy Act • Bank Secrecy Act - IRM
, Bank Secrecy Act (
) The primary law governing the authority for disclosure of federal tax tion is
USC
, commonly referred to as IRC
IRC
(a) establishes the conﬁdentiality of returns and return information and prohibits any disclosure not authorized by the Code. (

) The laws set forth other federal disclosure legal requirements, rules, and related statutes at the IRS. These laws relating to IRS disclosure or disclosure of tax and other sensitive information are codiﬁed at
USC
(Freedom of Information Act) and
a (Privacy Act), IRC
A,
, and
USC
Note: The Open Government and other general access statutes do not override the speciﬁc protections afforded tax returns and return information by IRC

IRC

11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
The tables below list commonly used terms, deﬁnitions and acronyms used throughout this IRM Section.
11.3.1.1.4 (11-12-2021) Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms

Terms Term Deﬁnition Disclosure The making known to any person in any manner whatever a return or return information. Return Any tax or information return, declaration of estimated tax, or claim for refund required by, or provided for or permitted under, the provisions of title 26 which is ﬁled with the Secretary by, on behalf of, or with respect to any person, and any amendment or supplement thereto, including supporting schedules, attach- ments, or lists which are supplemental to, or part of, the return so ﬁled. See IRC 6103(b)(1) for additional informa- tion.
or return information. Any tax or information return, declaration of estimated tax, or claim for refund required by, or provided for or permitted under, the provisions of title

which is ﬁled with the Secretary by, on behalf of, or with respect to any person, and any amendment or supplement thereto, including supporting schedules, attach- ments, or lists which are supplemental to, or part of, the return so ﬁled. See IRC
) for additional informa- tion.

Term Deﬁnition Return Information The deﬁnition of Return Informa- tion is very broad and includes such things as a taxpayer’s identity, the nature, source, or amount of his income, payments, receipts, deductions, exemptions, credits, assets, liabilities, net worth, tax liability, tax withheld, deﬁciencies, overassessments, or tax payments; whether the tax- payer’s return is subject to collection, examination, investiga- tion, or any other actions taken by the Secretary with respect to Federal ﬁling requirements. See IRC 6103(b)(2) for the statutory deﬁnition of return information. Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition BSA Bank Secrecy Act CAP Code, Authority and Procedure DAS Discriminant Analysis System FOIA Freedom of Information Act FTI Federal Tax Information GLDS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards GRS General Records Schedule GSS GLDS Support Services IRC Internal Revenue Code IT Information Technology NARA National Archives and Records Administration OGE Office of Government Ethics PA Privacy Act PGLD Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure PII Personally Identiﬁable Information PIIA Payment Integrity Information Act POA Power of Attorney

Before making any disclosure, every IRS employee must consider the Code Authority Procedure (CAP) process. Using a combination of the Code the IRC), Authority (such as Delegation Order 11-2, found in IRM 1.2.2.11.2, and other authorizations), and Procedures (contained in the IRM and other written guidance) ensures accurate determinations prior to disclosing, inspect- ing or recommending the release of IRS records.
a. Code: The IRC (
USC

) provides the statutory basis for prohibit- ing or allowing disclosure of returns or return information. b. Authority: The authority, generally established by Delegation Orders, lists the IRS officials with the authority to make the disclosure (or decision not to disclose). This includes: • Authorization to release and receive the information • Authentication of the recipient • Acceptance of information and any obligation placed on the recipient to protect the information disclosed • Access controls - i.e. “need to know”
Code: The IRC (
USC

) provides the statutory basis for ing or allowing disclosure of returns or return information. Authority: The authority, generally established by Delegation Orders, lists the IRS officials with the authority to make the disclosure (or decision not to disclose). This includes:

Authorization to release and receive the information Authentication of the recipient Acceptance of information and any obligation placed on the recipient to protect the information disclosed Access controls
i.e. “need to know”

Procedures: Established written procedures (in the IRM or other guidance) that explain the business process to follow for making a sure, and when required accounting for that disclosure. Procedures should help mitigate risks and prevent unauthorized disclosures.
Disclosure

) Each IRS employee is affected by laws governing the conﬁdentiality of and information in performing their assigned duties. The CAP process is to determine what information is conﬁdential, who may have access to it for what purposes, and how to account for its release. The CAP process is also used to determine what information must be made public and, if so, whether the information must be published, made generally available, or available only upon request. Additionally, the CAP process helps to how to restrict the types of personal information the agency gathers and maintains about individuals, and grants certain individuals the rights to and amend records about themselves. (
) Disclosure laws balance the competing interests of protecting the public’s personal and ﬁnancial privacy while maintaining open and effective tion of government. (
) Release of return and return information should always be limited on a to-know basis to the tax data that is needed (or necessary) for the speciﬁc purpose requested. (
) This IRM provides the instructions, guidelines, and procedures necessary to fulﬁll our obligations under the disclosure laws. (

) There are various resources available for both Disclosure personnel and all IRS employees that are useful in either responding to disclosure technical inquiries or in understanding their disclosure responsibilities. (

) The resources available for Disclosure personnel can be found on the sure home page on Share Point. Disclosure personnel needing assistance technical disclosure matters should seek assistance, through appropriate nels and procedures, from the staff of the Disclosure PPO office. Disclosure PPO will refer issues that require legal advice to the Office of Associate Counsel (Procedure and Administration) using agreed upon procedures and will provide guidance after receiving advice from Counsel. (

) IRS employees can ﬁnd many disclosure resources on the Disclosure and vacy Knowledge Base. Examples of disclosure topics that are available: a. Access and Authorization b. Power of Attorney (POA) and Tax Information Authorization (TIA) c. Risks at Work d. Unique Situations e. Respond Directly f. FOIA g. Disclosure Basics and contacts h. Taxpayer First Act (

) If an IRS employee still has a disclosure question, they can contact the sure Help Desk for advice on disclosure matters. Information on how to the Disclosure Help Desk is found on the Disclosure Basics and Contacts page.
This IRM provides the instructions, guidelines, and procedures necessary to fulﬁll our obligations under the disclosure laws.

) Records or ﬁles must never be destroyed while they are the subject of a pending request, appeal, or lawsuit under the FOIA, notwithstanding disposition schedules. (
